CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89% . The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones. Our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs . Corresponding Author *E - mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com ( W.Z. ) ; hbwu @ scut.edu.cn ( H.W. ) ; yongcao @ scut.edu.cn ( Y.C. ) .

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the "Material Name" entities in the given paragraph. We will present them in a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Here are the valid entities:

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PBDT-TDPP-S |
| PC71BM |
| ITO |
| PEDOT : PSS |
| MoO3 |
| Al |
| BHJ |
| PCE |

Here are the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph:

* PBDT-TDPP-S
* PC71BM
* ITO
* PEDOT : PSS
* MoO3
* Al
* BHJ
* PCE

Note that "BHJ" stands for "bulk heterojunction", and "PCE" stands for "power conversion efficiency".

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Of course! Here are the valid entities that refer to "Material name" in the given paragraph:

| --- |
| PBDT-TDPP-S |
| PC71BM |
| PEDOT : PSS |

I have removed the entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name", such as "ITO" and "MoO3", as they are not mentioned in the context of a material name. I have also presented the valid entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89% . The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones. Our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs . Corresponding Author *E - mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com ( W.Z. ) ; hbwu @ scut.edu.cn ( H.W. ) ; yongcao @ scut.edu.cn ( Y.C. ) .

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the property names of materials in the given paragraph. We will present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name". Here are the property names of materials mentioned in the paragraph:

| Property Name |
| --- |
| PBDT-TDPP-S |
| ITO |
| PEDOT |
| PSS |
| MoO3 |
| Al |
| PC71BM |
| active layer |
| hole - only device configuration |
| electron mobility |
| FF |
| surface morphology |
| surface roughness |
| prethermal annealing |

Note:

* PBDT-TDPP-S: This is the name of the conjugated polymer material.
* ITO: Indium tin oxide is a material used as a transparent electrode in solar cells.
* PEDOT: Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) is a conducting polymer used as an electrode in solar cells.
* PSS: Poly(styrene sulfonate) is a water-soluble polymer used as a binder in solar cells.
* MoO3: Molybdenum oxide is a material used as a hole transporting material in solar cells.
* Al: Aluminum is a material used as a metal electrode in solar cells.
* PC71BM: This is the name of a donor material used in the blend film.
* active layer: This refers to the layer of the solar cell that contains the light-absorbing material and is responsible for the photovoltaic effect.
* hole - only device configuration: This refers to the type of solar cell configuration where only holes are transported.
* electron mobility: This is the speed at which electrons move within the material.
* FF: This stands for fill factor, which is a measure of the efficiency of a solar cell.
* surface morphology: This refers to the texture and structure of the surface of the material.
* surface roughness: This refers to the roughness of the surface of the material.
* prethermal annealing: This is a process of heating the material to a temperature below the melting point to improve its properties.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Property name of material" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Of course! Here are the valid entities in the paragraph that refer to "Property name of material":

| Property Name |
| --- |
| PBDT-TDPP-S |
| PC71BM |

I have removed the following entities that do not clearly refer to "Property name of material":

* ITO (Indium tin oxide)
* PEDOT (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene))
* MoO3 (Molybdenum oxide)
* Al (Aluminum)

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89% . The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones. Our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs . | 0.602 nm | (surface roughness of annealed PBDT-TDPP-S blend film)
| 4.89% | (PCE of PBDT-TDPP-S blend film-based PSCs)

In the table, "Property Value" represents the value of the material property mentioned in the paragraph, and the entity is presented precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.
